content.description: Crimp up small holds on a vertical face following the right angling seam.  The jug to the right is a different route.
content.location: Just to the right of Pop Tart

content.description: This is the same route as Nova but with a sit start.  The sit start makes it much harder.

Harder than it looks!  This is a great problem that rewards balance and good beta more than strength.

Traverse right to left starting at the Junior Achievement Crack.  The route has two distinct halves, broken up by a good crack in the middle.  After a few easy moves the first half consists of techy, balancy climbing using small crimps and a mono.  After the crack you have some larger holds to work with, but they are spaced far apart.  The final rail is a bit pumpy after the rest of the traverse.

Overall a great problem with several thought provoking cruxes.  Maybe one of the best at Table Rock?
content.protection: Pads, although for most of the route you are no more than 12" off the ground.
content.location: Start at Junior Achievement and traverse left, eventually following the diagonal rail over the top.

content.description: Finger locks to jugs.  Pretty easy.
Starts at a small (12") roof.  Pull over the roof to slopey pockets and crimps.  Figuring out which edges are good and which just look good is half the battle.
content.location: The first roof encountered left of Bobby's traverse when walking along trail.

content.description: Step onto the wall using crimps and then "pop" for the flat-topped hold.  After latching this hold, make several more moves to your choice of moss covered holds to topout.
content.location: In the middle of the The Cutting Edge Traverse.

content.description: Fun and balancy laybacking up the finger crack.  This problem is pretty short, so it would be a good choice for those who don't like to climb high off the deck.
content.location: The first obvious thin crack on the left end of the wall below some bushes.

content.description: Start at big slopey ledge and lieback the crack.
content.location: Just around corner from Kobe's Forehead.

content.description: Make one move to a jug, and then a good sized reach to the fragile mossy rock above . . .
content.location: Located on the right end of the left-most wall in the Little Quarry.

content.description: A nice layback problem that is not too tough.
content.location: At the right end of the leftmost wall in the Little Quarry.

content.description: Step up and grab the jug, then continue grabbing jugs all the way to the top.
Approx. 45 feet of traversing left to right from a large crack to easy climbing.  Lots of good feet on this one, and a few sucker holds littered throughout as well.
content.protection: May want a pad.  Opportunities for heel bruises exist.
content.location: From The Little Quarry walk about 50 yards in the direction of the Big Times Area.  There are still some faint trails leading up to the wall.  If you come to the large patch of poison ivy you've gone too far.  You'll know this wall by the large knife-looking relief in the wall, and a large triangular hole further right.

content.description: Traverse from right to left, without using the top of the wall, starting in a shallow corner.  This climb has some fun sequences, but unfortunately it also has several ledges mixed in which interrupt the rhythm.
content.location: Starts a little left of the start for The Cutting Edge Traverse.
